title-group.article-title: Temperament styles of children from Pakistan and the United States

abstract.p: Age, gender, and cross-national differences of children ages 9 through 16 in Pakistan (n = 463) and the United States (n = 500) are examined on four bipolar temperament styles: Extroversion-introversion, practical-imaginative, thinking-feeling, and organized-flexible. In general, Pakistani children prefer extroverted over introverted, practical over imaginative, and organized over flexible styles. Although their preference for thinking and feeling styles is balanced, gender differences are significant. Males generally prefer a thinking style and females generally prefer a feeling style. Gender and age differences are found on practical-imaginative and organized-flexible styles. Cross-national differences are found on practical-imaginative and organized-flexible styles. In contrast to children in the US, children in Pakistan are more likely to prefer practical and organized styles.

body.p: The concept of temperament refers to stylistic and relatively stable traits that subsume intrinsic tendencies to act and react in somewhat predictable ways to people, events, and stimuli (Teglasi, 1988a, 1988b). Temperament traits generally are characterized as predispositions to display behaviors, with no assurance that people, events, and stimuli always will elicit the same temperament behaviors. Temperament traits appear early in life (e.g. Goldsmith et al., 1987; Thomas & Chess, 1977) and thus are assumed to have a biological origin, one tempered both by one's environment as well as personal choice (Bates & Wachs, 1994; Goldsmith et al., 1987; Kagan, 1994; Keogh, 2003; Oakland, Glutting, & Horton, 1996). Age and gender also are assumed to influence temperament.

Children's temperament can have a substantial impact on their behaviors, including their personal motivation, learning styles, peer and family relationships, and values (Bates & Wachs, 1994; Hofstede, 1980; Joyce, 2010; Keirsey & Bates, 1984; Keogh, 2003; Lawrence, 1982; Oakland et al., 1996). Temperament impacts vocational interests in children as young as 8 years (Oakland, Stafford, Horton, & Glutting, 2001) and may help distinguish children who display conduct and oppositional defiant disorders (Joyce & Oakland, 2005). Style preferences of sighted and non-sighted children have also been compared (Oakland, Banner, & Livingston, 2000). Thus, knowledge of children's temperament shows promise for use in understanding the impact of temperament on children's behaviors.

Research in the behavioral sciences increasingly reflects a need for cross-national information (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2007; Byrne et al., 2009; Hall & Altmaier, 2008; Wedding & Stevens, 2004). Such research examines the degree to which psychological traits or behaviors are consistent among people who differ culturally by virtue of their living in countries that differ by culture (Byrne et al., 2009; Strelau & Angleitner, 1994). An understanding of children's temperament from a cross-national perspective is important in light of international interest in temperament as well as the continuing debate concerning the extent to which temperament constructs are biologically or environmentally rooted (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2007; Hall & Altmaier, 2008; Joyce, 2010). Cross-national studies of temperament may provide evidence for temperament being biologically rooted and intrinsic to the individual and therefore forms universal human traits. Alternatively, studies may show temperament to be environmentally rooted. Information on temperament qualities in children and youth also may help establish the possible age of onset of these differences.

sec.title: Cross-national studies of children's temperament
sec.p:
Research by Oakland and his colleagues has relied on a model of temperament that includes four bipolar styles: Extroversion-introversion (e.g. the primary source of one's energy), practical-imaginative styles (e.g. how one prefers to process information), thinking-feeling (e.g. the basis on which people make decisions), and organized-flexible (e.g. when one prefers to make decisions) (Table 1). Their research is cognizant of emic and etic approaches (Berry, Poortinga, Segall, & Dasen, 1992) in their international studies of children's temperament, including those children in Australia (Oakland, Faulkner, & Bassett, 2005), Costa Rica (Oakland & Mata, 2007), Gaza (Oakland, Alghorani, & Lee, 2006), Greece (Oakland & Hatzichristou, 2010), Hungary (Katona & Oakland, 2000), India (Oakland, Singh, Callueng, & Goen, 2011), Japan (Callueng, de Carvvalho, Isobe, & Oakland, under review), Nigeria (Oakland, Mogaji, & Dempsey, 2006), People's Republic of China (Oakland & Lu, 2006), Romania (Oakland, Illiescu, Dinca, & Dempsey, 2009), South Africa (Oakland & Pretorisus, 2009), South Korea (Oakland & Lee, 2010), United States (Bassett & Oakland, 2009), Venezuela (Leon, Oakland, Wei, & Berrios, 2009), and Zimbabwe (Oakland, Mpofu, & Sulkowski, 2007). Emic approaches examine culture-specific traits while etic approaches examine whether traits and behaviors are universal and independent of one or more cultures. Initial research on any trait typically is directed toward describing the trait. Thus, the general purposes of this cross-national research are first to examine commonly displayed temperament traits of children within a country or region and then compare them with children in other countries or regions. This strategy is consistent with cross-national studies by McCrae & Costa (1997) and others (e.g. Berry, Poortinga, Segall, & Dasen, 1992; Macdaid, McCaulley, & Kainz, 1991; Plomin & Dunn, 1986) that examine the possible universality of temperament and personality traits.

sec.title: Proposes of this study
sec.p: The purpose of this research is to describe temperament style preferences in a sample of Pakistani students at four ages, to examine possible gender and age differences among them, and to compare their temperament style preferences with children in the US. The following questions are addressed in this study: Do Pakistani children display differences in their preferences for extroversion-introversion, practical-imaginative, thinking-feeling, or organized-flexible styles? Do they display gender and age differences on these temperament styles? Do Pakistani and US children differ in their preferences for these styles? A discussion of temperament preferences among US children, including age and gender differences, is not a primary focus of this study and can be found elsewhere (Bassett, 2005; Bassett & Oakland, 2009; Oakland et al., 1996). Data on US children are included to provide a direct cross-national comparison.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A sample of 463 Pakistani children was drawn from various private schools in three major cities of Pakistan: Karachi, Islamabad, and Quetta. Pakistan's national language is Urdu, and public school students typically are fluent only in their native language. Although public school students receive instruction in both English and Urdu, their minimal level of English language proficiency precludes the use of the SSQ—a measure typically administered in English. In contrast, private school students receive instruction mainly in English and thus are sufficiently fluent in English to complete the Student Styles Questionnaire (SSQ). Four age groups were formed: 9-year-olds (n = 126), 11-year-olds (n = 118), 13-year-olds (n = 111), and 15-year-olds (n = 108). Approximately 50% were males in each age group. All children came from upper middle socio-economic class families.

A sample of 500 US children was drawn from the US Student Style Questionnaire's standardization sample (Oakland et al., 1996). The sample formed the following four age groups with approximately 50% males in each group: 9- to 10-year-olds (n = 112), 11- to 12-year-olds (n = 164), 13- to 14-year-olds (n = 149), and 15- to 16-year-olds (n = 75). The US standardization data were designed to reflect 1990 US Bureau of the Census data. Thus, the US sample is stratified on five variables: Age, gender, race/ethnicity, geographic region, and school type. The subject pool of 7,902 public and private school children ranged in ages 8 through 17. Three racial/ethnic groups (Whites, Blacks, and Hispanics) were represented proportionately; approximately 50% were males in each racial-ethnic group.

sec.title: Instrument
sec.p: The Student Styles Questionnaire (SSQ; Oakland et al., 1996) is patterned after the Jungian constructs popularized by the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (Myers & McCaulley, 1985). The SSQ, a self-report paper and pencil group administered measure of temperament type for children ages 8 through 17, is completed within approximately 20 minutes. Each of its 69 forced-choice items has two alternatives that provide for an assessment of preferred behaviors associated with one of four bipolar traits: Extroversion (E) or introversion (I), practical (P) or imaginative (M), thinking (T) or feeling (F), and organized (O) or flexible (L). An example of an item assessing extroversion-introversion follows: ‘After school, I most prefer to spend time with others or spend time alone’. The EI scale has 23 items, the PM scale has 16 items, the TF scale has ten items, and the OL scale has 26 items. Additionally, six items provide information simultaneously on two scales.

Test–retest reliability coefficients, derived over an eight-month period, are 0.80, 0.67, 0.70, and 0.78 for EI, PM, TF, and OL respectively. Results of factor analyses studies indicate the SSQ's factor structure is consistent and stable for US children who differ by age, gender, and racial-ethnic group (Stafford & Oakland 1996a, 1996b). Factor analytic studies of data from children from seven countries generally found a stable factor structure and thus support the use of the SSQ internationally (Benson, Oakland, & Shermis, 2009). External validity, using contrasted groups, convergent validity, and divergent validity, provides additional strong support for the SSQ's validity (Oakland et al., 1996).

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: Educational institutions in Pakistan include public and private schools. The sample for this study was drawn from private schools that use English as the medium of instruction. This selection was designed to ensure children had sufficient English language proficiency to complete the SSQ. School administrators were informed about the purpose of the study and their willingness to cooperate was determined. They were provided a statement of the purposes of the study, forms on which parents could provide their consent and record demographic data, along with a copy of the Student Styles Questionnaire. Students for whom parent consent was obtained were tested in groups no larger than ten.

sec.title: Data analyses
sec.p: Temperament typically is considered to be a type rather than a continuous quality (Bassett, 2005; Bassett & Oakland, 2009; Buss & Plomin, 1984; Hall & Lindzey, 1978; Jung, 1921/1946; Lawrence, 1982; Macdaid et al., 1991; Plomin & Dunn, 1986; Rothbart & Jones, 1998; Teglasi, 1998b; Thomas & Chess, 1977). Personality also can be and often is viewed in its type form (McCrae & Costa, 1997). This belief guided the data interpretation methods

The frequency of Pakistani and US children expressing a preference for each of the eight types was determined in the following fashion. Individual responses on each of the 69 items were examined to determine whether a child selected more options from one of the two bipolar types. For example, among the 23 extroversion-introversion items, children who selected more extroverted than introverted options were classified extroverted. Conversely, children who selected more introverted options were classified introverted. Children who selected an equal number of options on a scale (e.g. extroversion-introversion) displayed no discernable preference on that bipolar type and thus were dropped from subsequent analyses on that scale. Fewer than 5% of the sample was excluded from one of the four bipolar types due to their experiencing an equal number of item preferences on one of the four scales.

Preliminary analysis involved the use of the chi-square (χ2) test to determine whether the frequency of Pakistani children who preferred either extroversion or introversion, practical or imaginative, thinking or feeling, and organized or flexible styles differ significantly in reference to total group. Logistic regression was used to examine the influence of age, sex, and country in differentiating the preferences of children in the four bipolar temperament traits. Logistic regression is deemed appropriate when the purpose is to predict categorical group membership (e.g. extroverted versus introverted styles) based on variables that are either continuous or discrete (Tabachnick & Fidell, 2006). Logistic regression analyses were conducted separately for each of the temperament traits to assess the extent to which gender and age influence the temperament style preferences of Pakistani children. Similarly, sequential logistic regression analyses were conducted to assess cross-national differences in temperamental style preferences, with gender and age as moderating variables. Odds ratios (OR) were used to assess the likelihood of preferences for a temperament style based on the explanatory variables of gender, age, and country. A 0.05 significance level was set for all analyses.

sec.title: Temperament styles of Pakistani children
sec.p:
Pakistani children prefer extroverted (59%) to introverted (41%) styles, χ2 (1) = 14.88, p < 0.001; practical (56%) to imaginative (44%) styles, χ2 (1) = 4.10, p < 0.05; and organized (83%) to flexible (17%) styles, χ2 (1) = 201.81, p < 0.001. Pakistani children have a somewhat balanced preference for thinking (48%) and feeling (52%) styles, χ2 (1) = 0.79, p < 0.05 (Table 2). The possible influence of gender and age on temperament styles preferences was examined using logistic regression analyses. Age and gender results are discussed below Table 2.

sec.title: Extroverted-introverted styles
sec.p: The general model for extroverted-introverted styles was not significant, χ2 (4) = 4.17, p > 0.05, Nagelkerke's R2 = 0.01, indicating that the combination of gender and age does not differentiate children's preferences on these styles. Gender, χ2 (1) = 2.92, p > 0.05, and age, χ2 (3) = 1.39, p > 0.05, were not associated with children's preferences for extroverted and introverted styles

sec.title: Practical-imaginative styles
sec.p: The general model for practical-imaginative styles was significant, χ2 (4) = 33.05, p < 0.001, indicating that the combination of gender and age differentiates children's preferences on these styles. These two variables account for approximately 11% of the variance in the children's preferences for practical and imaginative styles, Nagelkerke's R2 = 0.11. Gender, χ2 (1) = 4.54, p < 0.05, was associated with these styles with males more likely than females to prefer an imaginative style (OR = 0.63). Similarly, age, χ2 (3) = 1.80, p < 0.05, was associated with these styles with 9-year-old children more likely to prefer a practical style than older age groups: 11-year-olds (OR = 4.00), 13-year-olds (OR = 3.80), and 15-year-olds (OR = 3.44). Prediction success indicated that both gender and age correctly classified approximately 74% of children displaying a preference practical style and approximately 46% of children displaying a preference for imaginative style, with an overall success rate of approximately 62%.

sec.title: Thinking-feeling styles
sec.p: The general model for thinking-feeling styles was not significant, χ2 (4) = 7.22, p > 0.05, Nagelkerke's R2 = 0.03, indicating that the combination of gender and age does not differentiate children's preferences on these styles. However when age is controlled, gender was significantly associated with children's preferences for thinking-feeling styles, Wald χ2 (1) = 5.76, p < 0.01. Males are more likely to prefer a thinking style and females are more likely to prefer a feeling style (OR = 1.66). Prediction success indicated that both gender and age correctly classified approximately 44% of children displaying a preference thinking style and approximately 67% of children displaying a preference for feeling style, with an overall success rate of approximately 56%.

sec.title: Organized-flexible styles
sec.p: The general model for organized-flexible styles was significant χ2 (4) = 15.40, p < 0.01, indicating that the combination of gender and age differentiates children's preferences on these styles. These two variables account for approximately 6% of the variance in the children's preferences, Nagelkerke's R2 = 0.06. Gender was significantly associated with children's preferences for organized-flexible styles, Wald χ2 (1) = 8.15, p < 0.01. Compared to females, males are more likely to prefer a flexible type (OR = 0.46). Similarly, age was associated to children's preferences for organized-flexible styles, Wald χ2 (3) = 7.63, p < 0.05. Compared to 15-year-old children, 9-year-old children are more likely to prefer an organized style (OR = 5.40). Prediction success indicated that both gender and age correctly classified approximately 100% of children displaying an organized style and 0% of children displaying a preference for a flexible style, with and overall success rate of approximately 84%.

sec.title: Temperament styles of Pakistani and US children
sec.p: Sequential logistic regression analysis was employed to examine the influence of country on each of the four bipolar temperament traits with age and gender as moderating variables. Analysis was performed in the following manner. In Step 1, gender and age were entered in the equation to examine their contribution in differentiating temperament style preferences among Pakistani and US children combined. In Step 2, country was added to gender and age to examine its unique contribution, if any, in differentiating temperament style preferences over and above that of gender and age.

sec.title: Extroverted-introverted styles
sec.p: The general model from Step 1 was not significant, χ2 (4) = 1.89, p > 0.05, Nagelkerke's R2 = 0.00, thus indicating that the combination of gender and age does not differentiate children's preferences for extroverted and introverted styles. Gender, Wald χ2 (1) = 1.11, p > 0.05, and age, Wald χ2 (3) = 0.74, p > 0.05, were not associated with preferences for these temperament styles. When country was added in Step 2, the general model was not significant, χ2 (5) = 3.25, p > 0.05, ΔNagelkerke's R2 = 0.00, thus indicating that the addition of country in the model does not differentiate children's preferences for extroverted and introverted styles. Similar to gender (Wald χ2 [1] = 1.12, p > 0.05) and age (Wald χ2 [3] = 0.99, p > 0.05), country was not significantly associated with preferences for these styles, Wald χ2 (1) = 1.37, p > 0.05. Thus, children in Pakistan and the US do not display differences in their preferences for extroversion and introversion styles.

sec.title: Practical-imaginative styles
sec.p: The general model from Step 1 was significant, χ2 (4) = 13.02, p < 0.05, thus indicating that the combination of gender and age differentiates Pakistani and US children's preferences for practical and imaginative styles and accounts for approximately 2% of the variance in these styles, Nagelkerke's R2 = 0.02. Age was associated to preferences for practical-imaginative styles (Wald χ2 [3] = 12.32, p < 0.01) and gender was not (Wald χ2 [1] = 0.69, p > 0.05). Nine-year-old children are more likely than older children to prefer a practical style: 11-year-olds (OR = 1.83), 13-year-olds (OR = 1.70), and 15-year-olds (OR = 1.55).

When country was added in Step 2, the general model was significant, χ2 (5) = 27.12, p < 0.001, thus indicating that the addition of country in the model differentiates preferences for practical and imaginative styles and contributes approximately 2% of the variance in the preferences for these styles, Nagelkerke's ΔR2 = 0.02. Country was significantly associated to children's preferences for practical and imaginative styles, Wald χ2 (1) = 14.00, p < 0.001. Pakistani children are more likely to prefer a practical style and US children are more likely to prefer an imaginative styles (OR = 1.68). Consistent in Step 1, age (Wald χ2 [3] = 10.35, p < 0.05) was significantly associated with preferences for practical-imaginative styles and gender was not (Wald χ2 [1] = 0.68, p > 0.05). Prediction success indicated that the combination of country, gender, and age in Step 2 correctly classified approximately 52% of children displaying a practical style and 61% of children displaying an imaginative style, with an overall success rate of approximately 57%.

sec.title: Thinking-feeling styles
sec.p: The general model from Step 1 was significant, χ2 (4) = 82.39, p < 0.001, indicating that the combination of gender and age differentiates Pakistani and US children's preferences for thinking and feeling styles and accounts for approximately 12% of the variance in these styles, Nagelkerke's R2 = 0.12. Gender was associated to preferences for thinking-feeling styles (Wald χ2 [1] = 78.25, p > 0.001) and age was not (Wald χ2 [3] = 0.08, p > 0.05). Males are more likely to prefer a thinking style and females are more likely to prefer a feeling style (OR = 3.53).

When country was added in Step 2, the general model was significant, χ2 (5) = 84.31, p < 0.001. However, country did not contribute to the variance in thinking and feeling styles (ΔNagelkerke's R2 = 0.00). Both country (Wald χ2 [1] = 1.92, p > 0.05) and age (Wald χ2 [3] = 0.11, p > 0.05) were not significantly associated to children's preferences for these styles. Consistent in Step 1, gender (Wald χ2 [1] = 78.43, p < 0.001) was found to be associated to children's preferences for thinking-feeling styles (OR = 3.55). Prediction success indicated that the combination of country, gender, and age in Step 2 correctly classified approximately 65% of children who display a thinking style and 65% of children who display a feeling style, with an overall success rate of approximately 65%.

sec.title: Organized-flexible styles
sec.p: The general model from Step 1 was significant (χ2 [4] = 43.14, p < 0.001), thus indicating the combination of gender and age differentiates Pakistani and US children's preferences for organized and flexible styles and accounts for approximately 7% of the variance in these styles (Nagelkerke's R2 = 0.07). Gender was significantly associated with children's preferences for organized-flexible styles (Wald χ2 [1] = 18.01, p < 0.001). Compared to females, males are more likely to prefer a flexible style (OR = 0.51). Similarly, age was significantly associated to children's preferences for organized-flexible styles, Wald χ2 (3) = 24.68, p < 0.001. Compared to 13- (OR = 2.36) and 15-(OR = 3.06) year-old children, 9-year-old children are more likely to prefer an organized style.

When country was added in Step 2, the general model also was significant (χ2 [5] = 75.65, p < 0.001), thus indicating that the addition of country in the model differentiates children's preferences for organized and flexible styles and contributes approximately 5% of the variance in the preferences for these styles, ΔNagelkerke's R2 = 0.05. Country was significantly associated with preferences for organized and flexible styles, Wald χ2 (1) = 30.68, p < 0.001. Pakistani children are more likely than US children to prefer an organized style. Consistent in Step 1, gender (Wald χ2 [1] = 18.62, p < 0.001) and age (Wald χ2 [3] = 27.64, p < 0.001) were significantly associated to children's preferences for these styles. Thus, gender, age, and country reliably differentiate preferences for organized-flexible styles. Prediction success indicated that the combination of country, gender, and age in Step 2 correctly classified approximately 98% of children who display an organized style and 9% of children who display a flexible style, with an overall success rate of approximately 76%.

sec.title: Temperament preferences among children in Pakistan
sec.p: Pakistani children show discernable preferences for three of the four bipolar styles: Extroverted over introverted, practical over imaginative, and organized over flexible styles. Thus, one may characterize their prevailing temperament preferences as conveying a tendency to acquire energy more from others than themselves, to look at life more practically than imaginatively, and to prefer an organized life rather than one that has considerable freedom and flexibility. Although these style preferences are statistically supported, many—albeit less than 50% of Pakistani children—prefer introverted and imaginative styles. Few prefer a flexible lifestyle. They show a somewhat balanced preference for thinking and feeling styles. However, when making decisions, males are more inclined to prefer a thinking style (i.e. to be objective) while females are more inclined to prefer a feeling style (e.g. to be subjective). Age differences are most noticeable in children's preferences for practical and organized styles. Both are highly preferred at younger ages and decrease as children become older.

sec.title: Cross-national comparisons in temperament preferences––Pakistan and the US
sec.p: Children from Pakistan and the US do not differ in their preferences for an extroversion style. However, compared to US children, those in Pakistan are more likely to prefer practical and organized styles. For example, the majority of Pakistani children prefer a practical style while the majority of US children prefer an imaginative style.

Pakistani-US cross-national gender similarities are found on one bipolar style: Extroversion-introversion. However, gender differences are apparent on practical-imaginative styles (with the majority of Pakistani females favoring a practical styles in contrast to the majority of US females favoring an imaginative style), thinking-feeling styles (with a higher proportion of Pakistani than US males preferring a feeling style), and organized-flexible styles (with a higher proportion of Pakistani males and females than US males and females preferring an organized style).

sec.title: Preferences of children from Pakistan and 15 other countries
sec.p: Temperament style preferences displayed by Pakistani children are similar to prevailing qualities displayed by children in many of the 15 countries in which there are similar data. For example, children from 11 of the 15 countries also show a general preference for an extroverted style: Australia, Costa Rica, Greece, India, Japan, People's Republic of China, Romania, South Korea, United States, Venezuela, and Zimbabwe. Children from 11 countries also show a general preference for a practical style: Gaza, Greece, Hungary, India, Japan, Nigeria, People's Republic of China, Romania, South Africa, Venezuela, and Zimbabwe. Children from 14 countries also show a general preference for an organized style: Australia, Costa Rica, Gaza, Greece, Hungary, India, Japan, Nigeria, People's Republic of China, Romania, South Africa, US, Venezuela, and, Zimbabwe. Additionally, gender differences on thinking-feeling seen in Pakistani males and females also are seen in children from seven countries: Australia, Greece, Japan, Nigeria, People's Republic of China, South Africa, and United States.

Thus, the temperament preferences of children in Pakistan generally are similar to prevailing qualities displayed by children in other countries. Prior research found a stable factor structure and thus support the use of the SSQ internationally (Benson et al., 2009). Cross-national temperament data for children generally as well as for those who differ by age and gender from this and prior studies provide some support for the universality of temperament preferences (i.e. its etic qualities).

The results of this study may be viewed in reference to Pakistani culture as well as individual Pakistani children. A national view of these data should recognize that Pakistan is a collectivist society that emphasizes interdependence and conformity to socialized values and cultural (e.g. religious) norms. Deviation from these values and norms may result in condemnation. Parents and teachers socialize children to conform to society's standards and expectations as well as to maintain the country's and a family's traditions.

The finding that Pakistani children generally prefer practical and organized styles is consistent with this conforming orientation. Persons who display a preference for practical and organized styles typically strongly value engaging in institutions (e.g. families, religious organizations, work units) that provide stability to their country (Lawrence, 1982; Oakland et al., 1996). Their striving to be responsible, honest, dependable, and hard-working, to conform to society's rules and expectations, enjoy traditions, and work to maintain existing institutions and organizations is consistent with this value (Oakland et al., 1996, pp. 71–72)

Some people may view these temperament preferences to be due to living in a collectivist society and thus use these data to validate the assumption that culture strongly influences children's temperament styles. However, the belief that Pakistani culture may be due to biologically based temperament preferences, including general preferences for practical and organized styles as well as gender differences in which males generally rely more on their thinking and females on their feelings, also is viable. The view that Pakistanis may need to shape their society consistent with their prevailing temperament preferences rather than be shaped by their society also is viable.

A view of these data in light of individual children should acknowledge the impact temperament styles may have on their behavior (Horton & Oakland, 1977; Keirsey & Bates, 1984; Keogh, 2003; Lawrence, 1982; Oakland et al., 1996). Knowledge of a child's temperament styles can help the child, his or her parents and teachers understand the child's behavior, attitudes, preferred learning styles, and their other lifestyle preferences. This acknowledgement requires us to put aside group preferences for extroverted, practical, and organized styles and to focus on a child's individual preferences. Sizable percentages of children prefer styles that differ from prevailing preferences (e.g. 41% prefer introversion and 44% prefer imaginative styles). Children who display imaginative and flexible styles (e.g. those opposite from practical and organized styles) may deserve special attention. Their behaviors may deviate from the country's preferred values and norms and thus be subject to condemnation.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This is the first known report of temperament among Pakistani children. The availability of data from other temperament studies of Pakistani children and adults would allow us to examine the reliability of these finding and further trace possible age trends. Moreover, Pakistani children living in three major cities may not be representative of the Pakistani children living in rural areas. Additionally, the Pakistani and US samples are likely to differ by social class. The Pakistani children attended private schools and thus are likely to come from middle and upper class families; in contrast, the US children mainly attended public schools and are likely to come from families that reflect a broader income range. Thus, subsequent research that equates family social and economic status among students from the two countries is needed. Finally, temperament scales developed in light of Pakistani culture and standardized on Pakistani children may be preferable to those that are adapted for use in this country.

bio.p: Thomas Oakland, PhD, ABPP, ABPN, is Professor Emeritus at the University of Florida and Visiting Professor of Psychology at the University of Macau, the University of Hong Kong, Beijing Normal University-Zhuhai, Universidad Científica del Sur's (Peru) School of Psychology, and Honorary Professor, Universidad Nacional Frderico Villarreal, Lima, Peru. He received the American Psychological Association's 2003 Award for Distinguished Contributions to the Advancement of Psychology Internationally. He serves as President of the International Foundation for Children's Education and the International Association of Applied Psychologists' Division of Psychological Assessment and Evaluation. He is Past-President of the International School Psychology Association and the International Test Commission. Address: 1921 SW 8th Drive, Gainesville, FL 32601-8405, USA. Email: Oakland@ufl.edu

Camelo Callueng, MS, is a doctoral student in the University of Florida's school psychology program. His research interests include adaptive behavior, bullying, children's temperament, cognitive-behavior therapy, and test development and applications. Address: 1403 Normal Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville FL 32611-7047, USA. Email: carmelo@ufl.com
